title: How to know if I'm purchasing an authentic grimoire - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a great questionI The problem of authenticity of grimoire date back to the dark ages and in point of fact it is exceedingly difficult to find a grimoire with a chain of custody sufficient to establish authenticity. Adding to the problem as you can imagine since authentic grimoire are exceedingly rare, exceedingly small in number, one might say a vanishingly small number asymtotically approaching zero. This is unsurprising since most people on seeing one would assume that the writing there is some sort of random animal scratches as though ink and claw were drawn across the page and toss it into the trash. Some experts on Grimoire such as Professor Sybill Trelawney, PoD, hold that the scratches are actually just that, crudely forming runes in the which may, like tea leaves at the bottom of a cup, be read by those possessing the gift. Other experts have suggested that Professor Trelawney’s manifestly obvious myopia has created confusion over the nature of the runes. Those experts hold that the markings are in an ancient language and not at all something that must be “read” like tea leaves. At all events most practitioners of magick agree with professor Trelawney which is wholly consistent with the provenance of the grimoire themselves. The only question is why anyone would want the memoirs of large black spectral dogs in the first place.

First answer: don’t. Sacred Texts Archive has plenty, and they’re free. Read these first, they’ll give you an idea of what is typical of an historic text. Second answer: don’t be fooled by how “authentic” something looks. A knobby leather binding with clasps, parchment-looking sheets, antique-looking calligraphy, and lots of stains, doodling, and odd scripts is no guarantee of age or content. In fact, I’d hazard that the “parchment” is actually textured paper, and the whole was concocted as someone’s term project in art school, sometime in the Seventies. Learn what an actual old book looks like: the rag paper, the binding, what colors of ink they used. Study how Crowley’s Magical Records were kept: they were as clean as a lab notebook. Also: expect to pay. A lot. Third: if it says “Book of Shadows”, it’s modern. Case closed.

Do you read ancient Aramaic or Classical Greek? How about Coptic or can you decipher a translation from Medieval Latin into 16th century German? That’s how you know 99 times out of a 100 that an old book is not a real grimoire. Now of course a few have been translated into modern English, maybe but there would be very few copies and in special libraries like the Vatican. It’s good that they aren’t available as they would be ridiculously dangerous. Now I’m not referring to Books of Shadows that are occasionally published. They are books of a Witch’s trial and error and a collection of things that worked. My example would be a BoS is like a cookbook of things that work and have worked safely, while a grimoire is like directions for building a nuclear reactor written in code in an ancient dialect of a foreign language that’s designed to hurt anyone who it isn’t meant for. I would stay away from anything claiming to be a formal grimoire unless it’s just a name for a person’s spell book who you trust and have been given permission to look.

Apart from being astronomically expensive, you could only check its provenance. Have it inspected by an expert; a Professor with relevant expertise, from a prestigious University; someone from Sotheby's plus an expert in ancient languages, (unless you have the requisite knowledge to read it yourself).

Most of the truly authentic grimoires have been translated and published in modern form by Joseph H Peterson, who runs the Twilit Grotto website. If you head over there, and find it referenced then you can be assured that it is at least authentic as any grimoire can be. It would also help to search for Stephen Skinner and David Rankine on Amazon, as they have made a career of finding obscure manuscripts and publishing them.
You aren’t. There are none. You are either buying something that was intended as a grimoire and might have some antiquarian value or, more likely, you are being defrauded entirely.
Magic isn’t real so if you mean a magic one then you can be 100% sure the grimoire is not authentic.
